DOC.HEAD: Pennzoil Says It Won't Sue Chevron But Wants the Right To Do So
DOC.TEXT: The battle over Pennzoil Co.'s purchase of $2.1 billion worth of Chevron Corp. stock moved into murky legal waters Tuesday, with a Pennzoil lawyer asking a federal judge to lift restrictions on suing the rival oil giant but denying any intention to sue. ``People have a right to be in court,'' Stephen Bomse, a lawyer for Houston-based Pennzoil, said at a hearing on Chevron's request for a long-lasting order protecting it from suits by Pennzoil without court permission. He said the order ``would tie our hands.'' While Bomse insisted Pennzoil had no plans to sue Chevron over its anti-takeover maneuvers, Chevron lawyer William Edlund said Pennzoil has a history of ``hostile, non-passive investments,'' and added, ``Chevron suspects the motives of Pennzoil.'' U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson said he would rule within a few days, and meanwhile left another judge's order in place that requires Pennzoil to obtain the court's permission before suing San Francisco-based Chevron in any court over issues related to the case. Chevron, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, sued Pennzoil, the 14th-largest, on Dec. 7 after learning that Pennzoil bought 8.8 percent of Chevron's common stock. Pennzoil said it was making a long-term investment for tax purposes, to shelter the bulk of a $3 billion settlement it received from Texaco, and had no intention of acquiring control. Chevron challenged those statements, citing Pennzoil's past attempts at oil company acquisitions, and accused Pennzoil of concealing its purpose of a takeover or forced restructuring, in violation of federal securities law. The suit seeks to force Pennzoil to sell the stock and prohibit more purchases without court approval. At the same time, Chevron beefed up its defenses against takeovers, giving its directors a veto over purchases of stock purchases of more than 10 percent and arranging a $5 billion line of credit. Five groups of stockholders, none affiliated with Pennzoil, have sued Chevron management over those moves. Pennzoil says the suit is based on unfounded speculation and has moved to dismiss the case. Henderson, who will hear that motion Friday, has already ruled that the allegations in the suit are serious enough to give Chevron access to Pennzoil documents and executives _ orders Chevron says Pennzoil has largely resisted so far. When it filed the suit, Chevron obtained a temporary restraining order from Chief U.S. District Judge William Ingram prohibiting any related suits by Pennzoil without approval of the local court. Chevron sought an injunction Tuesday that would leave the prohibition in place until the court disposed of the case. ``Chevron believes that Pennzoil will be litigating,'' Edlund, Chevron's lawyer, told Henderson, saying such suits were common in takeover attempts. He said extending the restrictions would avoid multiple suits and should not harm Pennzoil, if it is telling the truth about its intentions. But Bomse said Chevron had failed to show any threat of harm that would entitle it to an injunction. ``You can't grant an injunction based on speculation, merely because Chevron ... may believe that Pennzoil is going to commence litigation,'' Pennzoil's lawyer said.
